PROBLEM LIST

What are the patient's previous problems (existed prior to this encounter?





  1. Refactory abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.
  2. Elevated liver function test (LFTs) with a cholestatic pattern.
  3. Antinuclear antibody and elevated ferritin measurements.
▼

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

What is the history of the patient's present Illness?

Mr. Leven was previously seen on 1/11/2019 for evaluation of refractory nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. During the interim, laboratory data was obtained confirming improved liver function studies with alkaline phosphatase 443, total billirubin 1.4, AST 36, and ALT 113. Of note, an acute viral hepatitis profile was obtained. documenting no evidence of viral hepatitis. In addition, the iron index is normal, thus refuting hemochromatosis, and prothrombin time is within reference range, suggesting adequate hepatic protein synthesis.



Currently the patient voices nausea, vomiting, and pain are less evident, although there have been 2 episodes since he was last seen. Reglan controls nausea, but his appetite remains suppressed.

▼

PHYSICAL EXAM

What findings were documented in the Physical Exam performed on the patient during this encounter?

LUNGS: Clear to auscultation and percussion.

ABDOMEN: Presently benign

▼

ASSESSMENT

What was the practitioner's assessment?

Regractory nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain wiht elevated liver function tests. Features appear concerning for cholestatic disease, potentially retained common bile duct gallstone, sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, or other obstructive disease. In addition, drug-induced hepatitis also is a possibility.

▼

What new goals have been set during this encounter for addressing concerns by the patient and/or provider?

What goals have been removed/completed by the patient and/or provider?

The patient will be scheduled for an MRCP to determine if there is underlying retained common bile duct stone.

If normal, then anticipate he may require an ERCP with manometry study to evaluate for sphicnter of Occi dysfunction. Lastly, repeat LFTs will be obtained in 1-2 weeks. Further recommendations will follow.
